bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Morris Fishbein, February 20, 1926

div1.p: Laura Carter sends photographs for Fishbein's article and describes her work with Henry Carter.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Morris Fishbein, February 20, 1926
div1.opener:
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
December 12, 1925.
Mr. James G. Martin, Atty. at Law,
700 Travelers Building,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
February 20, 1926.
Dr. Morris Fishbein,
Editor, Hygeia,
American Medical Association,
535 North Dearborn Street,
Chicago, Illinois.
Dear Doctor Fishbein:
div1.p: Your letter of February 18th. reached me a few minutes ago.

I am so glad that you were able to work up the article on
Father in your office and am looking forward to reading it with many
pleasant anticipations.

In regard to the pictures which you desire: I have just called
up the Library of the Public Health Service and the Librarian says
that all pictures on Ship Island in the Library will at once be sent
me from which to make a selection for you. I shall, of course, for-
ward them to you the day I receive them.

As to a picture of myself: I am enclosing (as most appropriate)
the only picute of Father and myself in existence. It is from a snap-
shot, taking during the International Sanitary Conference in Jamaica
summer before last. It has both the advantages and disadvantages of
being an absolutely unposed picture (indeed we didn't even know the
photograph had been taken until it appeared the next moring in “The Gleaner.”
The Gleaner."
-2-
As you can see, I had come up behind him and put my hand on his shoulder
in order to remind him that it was time to take his digitalis etc. (see
bottles in left hand), as I always had to “pursue” him after meals for this
purpose otherwise since, with his intense interest in the work of the Conference, he
would never have remembered it himself. I recall the incident well: his
smile as he realized my presence and a whimsical remark concerning “dutiful
parents” as he rose and accompanied me to take the medicine.

His holding his hand to his left side is not due to cardiac pain, al-
though he had been suffering from attacks of angina pectoris since the pre-
vious summer. It had been a characteric pose ever since he had had a coupl
of ribs broken during the World War. He had his side strapped at once and
continued his work without losing a day, He suffered a good deal from it,
however.

By the way, in addition to The History of Yellow Fever I also collaborated with Father in his "Malaria Catechism
(Pub. 1914)--see Introduction thereto--and worked with him, at $1.00 a year
in malaria control, for the two years of the War and in the reorganization
thereafter, up to the time of his departure for Peru. Also, of course, we
worked together from the time of his return to the States until his death.
within a few hours of the beginning of his last illness. It was a glorious
and inspiring association! Some day I hope to have the pleasure of meeting
you and telling you more about it.

With very best wishes, and rest assured I shall send on the Ship Is-
land pictures as soon as I receive them.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Laura Armistead Carter.
